articles.headline: Palestinians Set Bid for U.N. Seat, Clashing With U.S.
articles.snippet: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said he would seek membership from the Security Council next week.
articles.abstract: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said he would seek membership from the Security Council next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, announced Friday that he would seek membership for a state of Palestine from the United Nations Security Council next week, putting him on a collision course with Israel and the United States as both face an Arab world in turmoil.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: U.A.W. Reaches Tentative Agreement With General Motors
articles.snippet: The deal will help G.M.’s 48,500 union workers share in the company’s turnaround and should give them more job security.
articles.abstract: The deal will help G.M.’s 48,500 union workers share in the company’s turnaround and should give them more job security.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The United Automobile Workers and General Motors said late Friday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract.

articles.headline: Spotlighting 401(k) Plans, Thanklessly
articles.snippet: BrightScope, run by two brothers out of a crowded office in San Diego, is trying to turn its data mining and 401(k) plan rankings into a lasting business.
articles.abstract: BrightScope, run by two brothers out of a crowded office in San Diego, is trying to turn its data mining and 401(k) plan rankings into a lasting business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Up the stairs from the Chicken of the Sea offices in the northern reaches of this city, two brothers and about three dozen of their employees mine databases in a fledgling effort to help Americans retire a little sooner and manage their money a little better.

articles.headline: Cold-Water Detergents Get a Cold Shoulder
articles.snippet: The modest sales of cold-water laundry detergents suggest that skeptical consumers are more concerned about getting the clothes clean than being green.
articles.abstract: The modest sales of cold-water laundry detergents suggest that skeptical consumers are more concerned about getting the clothes clean than being green.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newly formulated laundry detergents can wash most clothes perfectly well in cold water, manufacturers say, but customers are stubbornly refusing to turn down the temperature. Although some of these detergents have been available for several years, customers cling to mom’s age-old advice that hot water washes best — squandering energy and contributing to greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Elisabeth Rosenthal

articles.headline: Support for Obama Slips; Unease on 2012 Candidates
articles.snippet: President Obama’s support is eroding among elements of his base, and Republicans have not coalesced around a candidate, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s support is eroding among elements of his base, and Republicans have not coalesced around a candidate, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s support is eroding among elements of his base, and a yearlong effort to recapture the political center has failed to attract independent voters, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, leaving him vulnerable at a moment when pessimism over the country’s direction is greater than at any other time since he took office.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Officials Eye Role of a Lawyer in Madoff Case
articles.snippet: A criminal referral is expected of a former S.E.C. general counsel who helped decide the agency’s plan for compensating Madoff victims.
articles.abstract: A criminal referral is expected of a former S.E.C. general counsel who helped decide the agency’s plan for compensating Madoff victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal ethics officials are expected to recommend that the Justice Department begin a criminal investigation into actions taken by David M. Becker, the former general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who determined the agency’s proposal for compensating victims of the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scheme when he had a financial interest in the outcome.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story

articles.headline: Columbia Professor Is Linked to Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: Dr. Andrew S. Bomback, a kidney expert, gave unpublished information to a hedge fund, prompting Massachusetts to regulate interactions between experts and traders.
articles.abstract: Dr. Andrew S. Bomback, a kidney expert, gave unpublished information to a hedge fund, prompting Massachusetts to regulate interactions between experts and traders.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was described only as “Doctor 1” in a Massachusetts insider-trading complaint against a hedge fund operator.

articles.headline: Spectators’ Deaths Highlight Risks of Popular Aerial Racing
articles.snippet: In Reno, Nev., the National Transportation Safety Board hopes to determine what caused a vintage plane to crash, killing at least nine people and maiming dozens.
articles.abstract: In Reno, Nev., the National Transportation Safety Board hopes to determine what caused a vintage plane to crash, killing at least nine people and maiming dozens.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — It was, for fans and followers of the high-speed sport of air racing, a sure sign of serious trouble: the vintage P-51 Mustang, the World War II fighter known as the “Cadillac of the skies,” pitching violently skyward in a frantic effort by the pilot to gain altitude — and to buy time.

articles.headline: The Guggenheim Connection
articles.snippet: As painted by the authorities, a case involving people accused of posing as representatives of the Guggenheim family is a tabloid monument to financial fakery.
articles.abstract: As painted by the authorities, a case involving people accused of posing as representatives of the Guggenheim family is a tabloid monument to financial fakery.
articles.lead_paragraph: LADY CATARINA PIETRA TOUMEI and her benefactor, David B. Guggenheim, late of the New York Guggenheims, will never rank among the great impostors. Victor Lustig sold the Eiffel Tower. Anna Anderson masqueraded as Anastasia. David Hampton posed as the son of Sidney Poitier, snookering high-caste Manhattan.

articles.headline: Suddenly, Over There Is Over Here
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s move to help European banks is but one sign that the euro zone’s crisis is hitting home.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s move to help European banks is but one sign that the euro zone’s crisis is hitting home.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE debt crisis in Europe has finally, and officially, washed up on American shores. Last week, the mighty Federal Reserve moved to help European banks that have been having trouble finding people who are willing to lend them money.

articles.headline: From an American in London, Global Warnings
articles.snippet: Adam Posen, an economist who found his unusual bully pulpit at the Bank of England by answering an ad in The Economist, wants central banks to print more money. A lot more money.
articles.abstract: Adam Posen, an economist who found his unusual bully pulpit at the Bank of England by answering an ad in The Economist, wants central banks to print more money. A lot more money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOTTON-UNDER-EDGE, England

articles.headline: Obama Tax Plan Would Ask More of Millionaires
articles.snippet: President Obama will seek a new minimum tax rate to ensure that people making more than $1 million a year pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-income taxpayers, administration officials said.
articles.abstract: President Obama will seek a new minimum tax rate to ensure that people making more than $1 million a year pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-income taxpayers, administration officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday will call for a new minimum tax rate for individuals making more than $1 million a year to ensure that they pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-income taxpayers, according to administration officials.

articles.headline: Tumult of Arab Spring Prompts Worries in Washington
articles.snippet: While the Arab Spring created new opportunities for American diplomacy, the tumult has also presented the United States with challenges — and worst-case scenarios.
articles.abstract: While the Arab Spring created new opportunities for American diplomacy, the tumult has also presented the United States with challenges — and worst-case scenarios.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the popular uprisings of the Arab Spring created new opportunities for American diplomacy, the tumult has also presented the United States with challenges — and worst-case scenarios — that would have once been almost unimaginable.

articles.headline: Autistic and Seeking a Place in an Adult World
articles.snippet: Justin Canha, a young artist with autism, prepares for life as an independent adult. Links to special features with Mr. Canha and his art can be found in the article text.
articles.abstract: Justin Canha, a young artist with autism, prepares for life as an independent adult. Links to special features with Mr. Canha and his art can be found in the article text.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — For weeks, Justin Canha, a high school student with autism, a love of cartoons and a gift for drawing, had rehearsed for the job interview at a local animation studio.

articles.headline: Obama Offers Plan to Cut Deficit by Over $3 Trillion
articles.snippet: President Obama unveiled a plan on Monday that uses entitlement cuts, tax increases and war savings to reduce the federal deficit by more than $3 trillion over the next 10 years.
articles.abstract: President Obama unveiled a plan on Monday that uses entitlement cuts, tax increases and war savings to reduce the federal deficit by more than $3 trillion over the next 10 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will unveil a plan on Monday that uses entitlement cuts, tax increases and war savings to reduce the federal deficit by more than $3 trillion over the next 10 years, administration officials said.

articles.headline: As an MSNBC Host, Sharpton Is a Hybrid Like No Other
articles.snippet: In his 6 p.m. news show on MSNBC, Al Sharpton will be both a maker and a deliverer of the news.
articles.abstract: In his 6 p.m. news show on MSNBC, Al Sharpton will be both a maker and a deliverer of the news.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 50 minutes to airtime, the Rev. Al Sharpton, in pinstripes and cufflinks, was sitting in his office at Rockefeller Center, tinkering with Tuesday’s introduction to “PoliticsNation,” his new nightly show on MSNBC.

articles.headline: Greeks Discuss Drastic Moves to Receive Aid
articles.snippet: Greek leaders struggled to agree to budget reductions that would satisfy foreign lenders’ demands even as they tried to stave off mounting resistance to those cuts at home.
articles.abstract: Greek leaders struggled to agree to budget reductions that would satisfy foreign lenders’ demands even as they tried to stave off mounting resistance to those cuts at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Greek leaders struggled through the weekend to agree to a set of radical budget reductions that would satisfy foreign lenders’ demands even as they tried to stave off mounting resistance to those cuts at home.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Facebook to Offer Path to Media
articles.snippet: The social media site’s new platform will allow its 750 million users to easily share their favorite music, movies and other forms of entertainment.
articles.abstract: The social media site’s new platform will allow its 750 million users to easily share their favorite music, movies and other forms of entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: For cloud-based digital music services like Spotify and Rhapsody, which stream millions of songs but have struggled to sign up large numbers of paying users, being friended by Facebook could prove to be a mixed blessing.

articles.headline: In Kabul, It’s Not MTV, It’s a Mission
articles.snippet: The man who brought us rock videos and “Beavis and Butt-Head” is advising a media group in Kabul that is shaking up television in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The man who brought us rock videos and “Beavis and Butt-Head” is advising a media group in Kabul that is shaking up television in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tom Freston is a pretty mellow guy, but sitting in the corner of a downtown Manhattan restaurant last week he was getting very excited as he talked about his new project. “Every time I go there, there are kids doing a bunch of new things, making all kinds of interesting programming,” he said. “The work they are coming up with is remarkable.”

articles.headline: In E-Books, Publishers Have Rivals: News Sites
articles.snippet: Swiftly and at little cost, newspapers, magazines and sites like The Huffington Post are publishing their own version of e-books.
articles.abstract: Swiftly and at little cost, newspapers, magazines and sites like The Huffington Post are publishing their own version of e-books.
articles.lead_paragraph: Book publishers are surrounded by hungry new competitors: Amazon, with its steadily growing imprints; authors who publish their own e-books; online start-ups like The Atavist and Byliner.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Scrutinizing Google’s Reign
articles.snippet: Google’s slogan may be don’t be evil, but a growing chorus of antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe want to know if the company has lived up to that creed.
articles.abstract: Google’s slogan may be don’t be evil, but a growing chorus of antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe want to know if the company has lived up to that creed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google’s slogan may be don’t be evil, but a growing chorus of antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe want to know if the company has lived up to that creed.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Fed Runs Risk of Doing Less Than Investors Expect
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is under pressure from investors to act to encourage growth and from Republican presidential candidates and others to refrain from acting.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is under pressure from investors to act to encourage growth and from Republican presidential candidates and others to refrain from acting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investors have concluded that the Federal Reserve will announce new measures to promote economic growth after a meeting of its policy-making committee ends Wednesday. Long-term interest rates have moved as if the Fed had already spoken.

articles.headline: Retiree Benefits for the Military Could Face Cuts
articles.snippet: A push in Congress to reduce the debt and the possibility that the Pentagon might have to begin trimming core programs have suddenly made retiree benefits vulnerable.
articles.abstract: A push in Congress to reduce the debt and the possibility that the Pentagon might have to begin trimming core programs have suddenly made retiree benefits vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Washington looks to squeeze savings from once-sacrosanct entitlements like Social Security and Medicare, another big social welfare system is growing as rapidly, but with far less scrutiny: the health and pension benefits of military retirees.
articles.byline: By James Dao and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Paint Creek, the Town Perry Left Behind
articles.snippet: The tight-knit and traditionally Democratic community of Paint Creek no longer wholeheartedly embraces Rick Perry, even as it anchors his origin story.
articles.abstract: The tight-knit and traditionally Democratic community of Paint Creek no longer wholeheartedly embraces Rick Perry, even as it anchors his origin story.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAINT CREEK, Tex. — In the early 1960s, at a tiny, rural school here in the rugged plains of West Texas, little Ricky Perry waged his first campaign. Seeking the office of Halloween King, he stocked up on penny candy at Ma’s convenience store and then doled it out to classmates.

articles.headline: Obama Draws New Hard Line on Long-Term Debt Reduction
articles.snippet: President Obama insisted that any long-term debt-reduction plan must not shave future Medicare benefits without also raising taxes on the wealthiest taxpayers and corporations.
articles.abstract: President Obama insisted that any long-term debt-reduction plan must not shave future Medicare benefits without also raising taxes on the wealthiest taxpayers and corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a scrappy unveiling of his formula to rein in the nation’s mounting debt, President Obama confirmed Monday that he had entered a new, more combative phase of his presidency, one likely to last until next year’s election as he battles for a second term.
